case_name: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal v. Messrs. S. Zoraster Co., Jaipur

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 30 of 1958 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 24, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 3 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 30 of 1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 24, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Reference No. 3 of 1953.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on August 17, 1960, by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. August 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This appeal, by special leave of this Court, is against the judgment and order dated March 24, 1955, of the Punjab High Court by which the High Court, purporting to act under s. 66 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act, called for a supplemental statement of the case from the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: The assessee is Messrs. S. Zoraster Co., Jaipur, consisting of three partners.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, Messrs. S. Zoraster Co., Jaipur, companysists of three partners. Two of them are companyarceners of a joint Hindu family, and the third is a stranger.

facts.text: Two partners of the assessee are coparceners of a joint Hindu family, and the third is a stranger.

anchor.surface_text: Two of them are companyarceners of a joint Hindu family, and the third is a stranger. They had formed this partnership in June, 1940, for the manufacture and sale of blankets, felts and other woollen articles.

facts.text: The partnership was formed in June 1940 for the manufacture and sale of blankets, felts and other woollen articles.

anchor.surface_text: They had formed this partnership in June, 1940, for the manufacture and sale of blankets, felts and other woollen articles. A deed of partnership was also executed on March 16, 1944.

facts.text: A deed of partnership was executed on March 16, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: A deed of partnership was also executed on March 16, 1944. The assessee entered into companytracts with Government for the sup- ply of goods, and in the assessment year 1942-43, Rs. 10,80,658-0-0 and in the assessment year 1943-44, Rs. 17,45,336-0-0 were assessed as its income by the Income-tax Officer, Contractors Circle, New Delhi.

facts.text: The assessee entered into contracts with Government for the supply of goods.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee entered into companytracts with Government for the sup- ply of goods, and in the assessment year 1942-43, Rs. 10,80,658-0-0 and in the assessment year 1943-44, Rs. 17,45,336-0-0 were assessed as its income by the Income-tax Officer, Contractors Circle, New Delhi.

facts.text: In assessment year 1942-43, Rs. 10,80,658 were assessed as income of the assessee by the Income-tax Officer, Contractors Circle, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: and in the assessment year 1942-43, Rs. 10,80,658-0-0 and in the assessment year 1943-44, Rs. 17,45,336-0-0 were assessed as its income by the Income-tax Officer, Contractors Circle, New Delhi. The supplies to Government were made for. Jaipur by the assessee, and payment was by cheques which were received at Jaipur and were endorsed in favour of the joint Hindu family, which acted as the assessees bankers.

facts.text: In assessment year 1943-44, Rs. 17,45,336 were assessed as income of the assessee by the Income-tax Officer, Contractors Circle, New Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: and in the assessment year 1942-43, Rs. 10,80,658-0-0 and in the assessment year 1943-44, Rs. 17,45,336-0-0 were assessed as its income by the Income-tax Officer, Contractors Circle, New Delhi.

facts.text: Supplies to Government were made for Jaipur by the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The supplies to Government were made for. Jaipur by the assessee, and payment was by cheques which were received at Jaipur and were endorsed in favour of the joint Hindu family, which acted as the assessees bankers.

facts.text: Payment was by cheques which were received at Jaipur and endorsed in favour of the joint Hindu family, which acted as the assessee's bankers.

anchor.surface_text: and payment was by cheques which were received at Jaipur and were endorsed in favour of the joint Hindu family, which acted as the assessees bankers. The companytention of the assessee was that this income was received at Jaipur outside the then taxable territories.

facts.text: Assessee's contention was that the income was received at Jaipur outside the then taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the assessee was that this income was received at Jaipur outside the then taxable territories. This companytention was number accepted by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Delhi.

facts.text: The assessee's contention was not accepted by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention was number accepted by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Delhi. The assessee then applied for a reference to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, and by its order dated December 10, 1952, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court

facts.text: The assessee applied for a reference to the High Court under s. 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then applied for a reference to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act, and by its order dated December 10, 1952, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court

facts.text: By order dated December 10, 1952, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred the question 'Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the profits and gains in respect of the sales made to the Government of India were received by the assessee in the taxable territories?'

anchor.surface_text: and by its order dated December 10, 1952, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal referred the following question for the decision of the High Court Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the profits and gains in respect of the sales made to the Government of India were received by the assessee in the taxable territories ?

facts.text: The payment was made by the Government of India by cheques drawn on the Reserve Bank of India, Bombay Branch.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal had stated in the statement of the case as follows The payment was made by the Government of India by cheques drawn on the Reserve Bank of India, Bombay Branch. These cheques were received in Jaipur.

facts.text: The cheques were received in Jaipur.

anchor.surface_text: These cheques were received in Jaipur. It may be pointed out that in the companytract of sale between the assessee and the Government of India, the following clause was included to determine the system of payment

facts.text: The contract of sale between the assessee and the Government of India included a clause on system of payment: 'Unless otherwise agreed between the Purchaser and the Contractor payment for the delivery of the stores will be made by the Chief Auditor, Indian Stores Department, New Delhi, by cheque on a Government treasury in India or on a branch of the Imperial Bank of India or the Reserve Bank of India transacting Government business.'

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that in the companytract of sale between the assessee and the Government of India, the following clause was included to determine the system of payment System of payment-Unless otherwise agreed between the Purchaser and the Contractor payment for the delivery of the stores will be made by the Chief Auditor, Indian Stores Department, New Delhi, by cheque on a Government treasury in India or on a branch of the Imperial Bank of India or the Reserve Bank of India transacting Government business.

facts.text: The High Court passed an order under s. 66(4) of the Income-tax Act directing the Tribunal to find whether the cheques were sent by post or by hand and what directions the assessee firm had given to the Department.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the Reference, the High Court passed an order under s. 66 4  of the Income-tax Act observing, it would be necessary for the Appellate Tribunal to find, inter alia, whether the cheques were sent to the assessee firm by post or by hand and what directions, if any, had the assessee firm given to the Department in the matter .

facts.text: The High Court remanded the case to the Tribunal for a supplemental statement of the case.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court thereafter remanded the case to the Tribunal for a supplemental statement of the case on the lines indicated. This order is questioned on the authority of the decision of this Court in The New Jehangir Vakil Mills Ltd.

facts.text: The special leave granted by this Court is limited to the question whether the High Court had jurisdiction to call for the supplemental statement.

anchor.surface_text: The special leave granted by this Court is limited to the question whether the High Court had jurisdiction in this case to call for the supplemental statement.

facts.text: Gopal Singh appeared for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Gopal Singh, for the appellants. N. Rajagopala Sastri and D. Gupta, for the respondent. 1960. August 17.

facts.text: N. Rajagopala Sastri and D. Gupta appeared for the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: N. Rajagopala Sastri and D. Gupta, for the respondent. 1960. August 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This appeal, by special leave of this Court, is against the judgment and order dated March 24, 1955, of the Punjab High Court by which the High Court, purporting to act under s. 66 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act, called for a supplemental statement of the case from the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: The joint Hindu family acted as the assessee's bankers.

arguments.claim: The High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under s.66(4) by calling for a supplemental statement, as completely covered by New Jehangir Vakil Mills Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: This order is questioned on the authority of the decision of this Court in The New Jehangir Vakil Mills Ltd. The Commissioner of Income-tax 1 which, it is claimed, completely covers this case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the parties to direct the Tribunal to state further facts so that we may properly exercise our own advisory jurisdiction. This Court pointed out that

arguments.court_reasoning: Question referred in this case is wide unlike narrow question in Jehangir Vakil Mills.

arguments.claim: Necessary for Appellate Tribunal to find whether cheques were sent by post or hand and directions given by assessee to Department.

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the Reference, the High Court passed an order under s. 66 4  of the Income-tax Act observing, it would be necessary for the Appellate Tribunal to find, inter alia, whether the cheques were sent to the assessee firm by post or by hand and what directions, if any, had the assessee firm given to the Department in the matter .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: finds support from yet another case of this Court decided very recently. In Kusumben D. Mahadevia v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay  2 , it was obs

arguments.court_reasoning: Direction interpreted as confined to facts admitted or found by Tribunal, not requiring fresh evidence.

arguments.claim: High Court has right under s.66(4) independently of parties' conduct to direct Tribunal for further facts to exercise advisory jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: But we cannot shut out the necessary inquiry which even from our own point of view is necessary to be made in order that we should satisfactorily answer the question raised in the Reference. It must not be forgotten that under section 66 4  of the Income-tax Act we have a right independently of the conduct of the parties

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s at Bhavnagar without advertence to the fact whether the cheques were so sent by post at the request, express or implied, of the Mills. The question

arguments.court_reasoning: s.66(4) does not enable raising new question of law or investigating new facts not arising from Tribunal's order.

arguments.claim: Jehangir Vakil Mills sets two limits on High Court jurisdiction under s.66(4): confined to facts admitted/found by Tribunal and question arising from Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: The case thus set two limits to the jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 66 4 , and they were that the advisory jurisdiction was confined  a  to the facts on the record and or found by the Tribunal and  b  the question which would arise from the Tribunals order.

arguments.claim: Question referred is wide enough to include whether request express or implied to send cheque by post, unlike narrow question in Jehangir Vakil Mills.

anchor.surface_text: We have thus to see whether in this case the question which was decided and which has been referred to the High Court admits the return of the case for a supplemental statement on the lines indicated by the High Court in the order under appeal. At the very start, one notices a difference in the question of law in this case and the Ogale Glass Works case

arguments.claim: High Court direction does not transgress second limit as it can be interpreted to confine to facts already admitted or found by Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the High Court has transgressed the second limitation implicit is s. 66 4 , that is to say, that the question must arise out of the facts admitted and or found by the Tribunal. The High Court has observed that, it would be necessary for the Appellate Tribunal to find inter alia whether the cheques were sent to the assessee firm by post or by hand

arguments.qualifiers: in the absence of anything expressly to the contrary

arguments.claim: Income was received at Jaipur outside taxable territories as cheques received there.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the assessee was that this income was received at Jaipur outside the then taxable territories. This contention was not accepted by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Delhi.

arguments.claim: In Jehangir Vakil Mills, High Court exceeded jurisdiction by raising new question on post request not in Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction. Before dealing with this question, it is necessary to go back a little, ... This Court pointed out that the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction under s. 66 4  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

arguments.claim: Intimation to payer to remit by cheque constitutes post office as agent of payee; receipt at posting place.

anchor.surface_text: an intimation to the payer to remit the amount by cheque was sufficient constitution of the post office as the agent of the payee vide Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.

arguments.claim: Endorsement on bills 'Government should pay by cheque' constitutes implied request for post office as agent.

anchor.surface_text: Later, the principle was extended still further by this Court in Jagdish Mills case . It was held that where the bills had an endorsement Government should pay the amount due by cheque and the cheques were received in full satisfaction unconditionally, this constituted a sufficient implied request

holdings.text: The first limit to the jurisdiction of the High Court as laid down by this Court is thus not exceeded by the High Court in exercising its powers under s. 66(4) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is thus quite plain that the question as framed in this case can include an enquiry into whether there was any request, express or implied, that the amount of the bills be paid by cheques so as to bring the matter within the dicta of this Court in the Ogale Glass Works case  2  or Jagdish Mills case  3 . The first limit to the jurisdiction of the High Court as laid down by this Court is thus not exceeded by the High Court in exercising its powers under s. 66 4  of the Income-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The referred question 'Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the profits and gains... were received by the assessee in the taxable territories' is wide enough to include inquiry into express or implied request to send cheques by post, distinguishing narrow question in Jehangir Vakil Mills.

holdings.text: The direction cannot be described as in excess of the jurisdiction of the High Court as it can be interpreted to confine the Tribunal to facts admitted or found by it.

anchor.surface_text: If, however, the direction be interpreted to mean that the Tribunal in giving the finding must confine itself to the facts admitted and or found by it, the direction cannot be described as in excess of the jurisdiction of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's order to find if cheques sent by post/hand and directions given interpreted, absent express contrary indication, as limited to existing record facts without fresh evidence, consistent with Jehangir Vakil Mills limits.

holdings.text: The advisory jurisdiction under s.66(4) is confined (a) to the facts on the record and/or found by the Tribunal and (b) the question which would arise from the Tribunal's order.

anchor.surface_text: The case thus set two limits to the jurisdiction of the High Court under s. 66 4 , and they were that the advisory jurisdiction was confined  a  to the facts on the record and or found by the Tribunal and  b  the question which would arise from the Tribunals order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reaffirming and applying the two limits on High Court power under s.66(4) as established in New Jehangir Vakil Mills Ltd. to the facts of this case.

holdings.text: Section 66(4) does not enable the High Court to raise a new question of law which does not arise out of the Tribunal's order and direct investigation of new facts.

anchor.surface_text: But s. 66 4 does not enable the High Court to raise a new question of law which does not arise out of the Tribunals order and direct the Tribunal to investigate new or further facts necessary to determine this new question

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quoting and applying principle from Jehangir Vakil Mills to delineate scope of s.66(4), distinguishing from mere reframing for clarity.

precedents.case_name: Kirloskar Bros. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: mere posting of cheque not receipt unless payee requested post as agent
precedents.cited_holding: mere posting of the cheque in Delhi was not tantamount to the receipt of the cheque in Delhi, because the payee had not requested the Government to send the cheque by post

precedents.citation: Ogale Glass Works Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 4

precedents.case_name: Ogale Glass Works Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: no express request for post means receipt where cheque received, not posted
precedents.cited_holding: as there was no such express request, the receipt of the money was not where the cheque was posted but at the place where the money was received

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the High Court has transgressed the second limitation implicit is s. 66 4 , that is to say, that the question must arise out of the facts admitted and or found by the Tribunal. The High Court has observed that, it would be necessary for the Appellate Tribunal to find inter alia whether the cheques were sent to the assessee firm by post or by hand and what directions, if any, bad the assessee-firm given to the Department in that matter. If the Tribunal has to make a fresh enquiry leading to the admission of fresh evidence on the record, then this direction offends against the ruling of this Court in the Jehangir Vakil Mills case

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order under s. 66(4) upheld; no excess of jurisdiction; direction interpreted as confined to existing record

anchor.surface_text: It is thus quite plain that the question as framed in this case can include an enquiry into whether there was any request, express or implied, that the amount of the bills be paid by cheques so as to bring the matter within the dicta of this Court in the Ogale Glass Works case  2  or Jagdish Mills case  3 . The first limit to the jurisdiction of the High Court as laid down by this Court is thus not exceeded by the High Court in exercising its powers under s. 66 4  of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the High Court has transgressed the second limitation implicit is s. 66 4 , that is to say, that the question must arise out of the facts admitted and or found by the Tribunal. If the Tribunal has to make a fresh enquiry leading to the admission of fresh evidence on the record, then this direction offends against the ruling of this Court in the Jehangir Vakil Mills case
